attributes.title: Proportionate Immigration Control
attributes.description:
Immigration is one of the most complex challenges of an increasingly globalized world.  It is the issue that many scholars argue is at the heart of the populist backlash that has recently characterized the Western political landscape.  There is a deep and diverse literature that has explored the sources of resistance to immigration among native citizens.  However, these explorations are often very narrow in scope, with people being polled about their general support for immigration, which specific groups should be allowed to immigrate, and which services they should have access to.  A great deal less is known about how people consider and potentially support different methods of exclusion or removal, such as visa processes, detention, and the use of violent force.  The characterization is similarly limited among political philosophers, with theorists either supporting broad immigration controls or not, or supporting the admitting of some groups or not.  There is little work on whether certain means of immigration control are justified. 

The present work first identifies a key principle – the principle of proportionality – that is present in other areas of political philosophy concerning the use of coercive force. It considers how this principle might be applied to immigration control, concluding the following ethical philosophical principle: the more force that is necessary for preventing a migrant from remaining in a country, the less justified such prevention is. We then establish whether this general philosophical principle is supported by citizens. We do so by presenting subjects with experimental vignettes of migrants who failed to obtain a visa to live in the UK, with the level of force necessary to deport the migrant varying. Subjects are asked to decide if and to what extent excluding this migrant is reasonable, helping us evaluate the extent that citizens view force as lowering the justification for excluding a migrant.

q2.value:
1.	There is at least a weak inverse relationship between citizens’ support for exclusion and the extent that force used to bring about this exclusion causes likely harm. 
2.	There is at least a weak inverse relationship between citizens’ support for exclusion and the severity of the harm caused from force used to bring about this exclusion. 
3.	The more subjects are pro-humanitarian, the less they will support violent means of immigration control.
4.	The more educated subjects are, the less they will support violent means of immigration control.
5.	The subjects that are higher in trait empathy will support violent means of immigration control less. 
6.	Citizens will be more supportive of lethal force the more an immigrant is perceived as a threat to security.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
To test these hypotheses, we will conduct an online survey of using experimental vignettes (Atzmuller and Steiner 2010; Hainmueller et al 2015; Turper 2017) to evaluate the extent that subjects support or oppose the use of violence in immigration control. Subjects will be presented with eight vignettes involving a fictional migrant who seeks to enter or remain in the United Kingdom. They will be asked to decide the extent that denying this migrant the right to live in the UK is reasonable on a scale of 1 to 7. 

In addition to the above online survey, we will conduct in-person in-depth qualitative interviews to better understand why individuals support or object to a given means of immigration control and to understand individuals’ potential rationales behind views concerning immigration enforcement.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Payment and experiment completion time (finalized following pilot testing): 
£3.20 for a 25-minute experiment completed online.

Subject selection method: 
The sample of subjects for the online experiment will be collected from Prolific Academic and will be composed solely of individuals classified as British nationals.

q11.value: Data collection from the experiment will cease when we reach 1500, (+/– 50 based on demographic balance).

q12.value: Based on a simulated power calculation with three experimental conditions, data collection from the experiment will cease when we reach 1500, (+/– 50 based on demographic balance).  The figure on page 9 in the attached document, labeled "Proportionate Immigration Control," displays the results of the simulation, and estimates of statistical power over numbers of recruited participants, with the red line signifying statistical power of .80.

question.value:
Manipulated variables:
Each vignette will randomly vary along the following attributes:

Manipulated outside of the conjoint framework:
We have three experimental conditions based on the perceived likelihood of consequences of migration restrictions for migrants (though all tasks still remain hypothetical).  In Condition 1, participants are provided with certain information.   In Condition 2, participants are provided with information that is probabilistic (low, high, or near certain chances of consequences.  Finally, in Condition 3, participants are provided with no information about what happens to the migrant in the vignette.

Manipulated within the conjoint framework:
a.	Prospective (seeking to enter the UK) vs. retrospective (seeking to remain in the UK).
b.	Country of origin of migrant, collapsed by region (4 levels; Africa, Eastern Europe, Middle East, Asia)
a.	Africa:  Nigeria, Ethiopia, South Africa, Kenya
b.	Eastern Europe: Poland, Romania, Russia, Ukraine
c.	Middle East:  Iran, Syria, UAE, Israel
d.	Southeast Asia:  India, Bangladesh, Pakistan, Myanmar
c.	Migrants’ reasons for attempting to enter the UK.  More specifically, subjects will be randomly assigned vignettes with one of the following three variables: 
1)	Entering/wishing to remain in the UK to seek economic opportunity,
2)	Entering/wishing to remain in the UK to flee life-threatening poverty
3)	Entering/wishing to remain in the UK to flee persecution
4)	Entering/wishing to remain in the UK for medical treatment
d.	Their reasons for being denied a visa to live in the UK.
1)	They have a criminal record
2)	They lack employment in the UK 
3)	Their name is on a terrorism watch-list
4)	Immigration quotas do not permit it
5)	They are tested positive for COVID-19
e.	The means of removal of the migrant
1)	The method: detaining or deporting 
2)	The potential consequences:  
a.	bodily injury due to detention/deportation
b.	death due to detention/deportation
c.	bodily injury due to reason for immigration (e.g. illness) 
d.	death due to reason for immigration (e.g. illness)
e.	safe return to country of origin
f.	unknown

Measured variables:  (note:  full inclusion subject to duration of pre-tested survey)
1.	Key dependent variable:  Subjects will be asked how reasonable it is to support the exclusion/removal of a given immigrant in the vignettes described above. 
We will also measure the subject’s: 
2.	Gender 
3.	Education 
4.	Income
5.	Humanitarian orientation (Feldman and Steenbergen 2001)
6.	Reading the Mind in the Eyes task (Baron Cohen et al)
7.	Ideology
8.	Votes in previous elections
9.	Attitudes towards immigration restrictions in general, 
10.	Preferred methods of immigration control (deportation, detaining, denial access of healthcare, blanket amnesty, limited amnesty, no immigration control). 

The above measurements will be collected using a questionnaire found in the attached supplemental document, labeled, "Border_Control_Prolific_Study_March_2020."

We plan to analyse the results of the conjoint using OLS regression to model the impact of the experimental treatments and the conjoint attributes on the 7pt rating of how acceptable participants found the circumstances.  
We will also examine results for subgroup effects, in-line with our hypotheses, over the following characteristics:
1.	Humanitarianism 
2.	Empathy (Mind in the Eyes Task)
3.	Ideology
4.	Education
5.	Harshness of general immigration stance

All comparisons will be done by running separate models using the bottom and top quartiles on these scales/items.

q23.value:
Theoretical background: 
States use diverse mechanisms to deport migrants or prevent their entrance. States use physical violence to force migrants onto planes, at times suffocating them to death or injecting psychiatric drugs into those resisting (Fekete 2005; Weber and Pickering 2013; Gibney 2013). States detain migrants until they agree to leave (Corlett 2003 at 105-111; Blitz et al 2005; Abdi 2005; Webber 2011) and sometimes raid migrants’ homes while they sleep, restraining anyone attempting to flee. States sometimes deny basic necessities to migrants, hoping to encourage them to leave on their own accord (Abdi 2005, Blitz et al 2005) and have begun paying migrants to leave, offering thousands of euros to those agreeing to return home (Gerver 2018a, Dadush 2018, Webber 2011; Omata 2011; Smith 2010). Some states even pay other states to host the migrants they do not desire, as when European states paid Libya to keep migrants within its borders, and Turkey to keep refugees within its borders (Sandel 2012; Gerver 2018b). Most famously, states have begun building thicker, higher, and more numerous walls, increasingly using lethal force against those circumventing these walls (Brown 2010). In some cases, states outsource such force to volunteers, as in the US where minute men patrol the border with guns in hand (Chavez 2006; Vina 2006; Yoxall 2006; Lind and Williams 2016). And when migrants do manage to enter, some states separate parents from their children, making it more difficult for children to defend their rights, giving families additional incentives to avoid entering to begin with. 

Despite the diversity of immigration control mechanisms in reality, a consideration of public support for these means of exclusion is conspicuously absent.  Pollsters and researchers rarely ask citizens to indicate which control mechanisms they support, instead focusing on general support for immigration and which categories of migrants they support excluding (Aalberg, et al 2012; Citrin et al 1997; Dustmann and Preston, 2007; Facchini and Mayda 2009; Hainmueller and Hiscox 2010; Harell et al 2012; Johnston et al 2015; Mayda, Anna Maria 2006; Newman et al 2015; Quillian 1995; Scheve and Slaughter 2001; Schildkraut 2011; Sniderman 2002, 2004; Wright and Citrin 2011).  For example, a consistent finding across a number of studies indicates that citizens support immigrants who are highly skilled, have no criminal background, are of certain nationalities and races, and display a high likelihood of assimilation, particularly in terms of speaking the language of the host country (Hainmueller and Hopkins 2015; Turper 2017; Citrin & Sides 2008; Turper 2017, Dustmann and Preston 2007; Hainmueller and Hangartner 2013).  These studies do not address whether citizens who support the exclusion of certain immigrants also support all means of exclusion. 

Similarly, studies addressing whether certain types of citizens are more likely to support immigration do not address whether certain types of citizens are more likely to support certain mechanisms for exclusion (Mayda 2006). For example, studies find that those who are more educated or who hold humanitarian tendencies are more supportive of immigration (Citrin and Sides 2008, Lahav 2004 ) while those holding negative stereotypes or biases about immigrants are less supportive of immigration (Burns and Gimpel 2000, Pe ́rez 2010). It remains unclear whether these characteristics predict certain opinions regarding when states ought to use force, detention, payments, and other means of exclusion. 

It is not only social science which overlooks the question of mechanisms for immigration control.  This question is also overlooked in philosophy. Political philosophers focusing on the ethics of immigration controls tend to fall into two camps. The first we call inclusive philosophers, who claim states almost never have a moral right to deny entrance to immigrants (Oberman 2016, Carens 1987), and the second we call exclusionary philosophers, who claim states always or sometimes have a moral right to deny entrance to immigrants (Wellman 2008, Miller 2005, 2016, Gibney 2004, Ypi 2016). Neither camp addresses whether some means of exclusion are unjustified even if the ends are. For example, even if denying visas to potential immigrants is justified, lethally shooting immigrants attempting to arrive may not be. Similarly, even if deporting migrants using force is justified, separating parents from their children need not be. 

More generally, what is missing in discussions in both social science and philosophy is a focus on proportionality. The principle of proportionality, commonly raised in discussions on war and criminal justice, holds that an act which involves far greater harm than justified for a given end is morally impermissible (Gross 1979: 436, Fish 2008, von Hirsch 2005; McMahan 2014 at pages 6-9; May 2007 at ch. 10; McMahan 2016). For example, it is wrong to institute the death penalty for someone who has committed the mere crime of theft, even if this will deter theft, as the end of deterrence does not justify the means of death. Similarly, it is wrong to drop a bomb on a civilian population to end a war, because the means of intentionally killing civilians may be disproportionate to the end of winning the war. Just as killing the thief and civilians is wrong, it might be wrong to use some types of force to compel migrants to leave, even if the ends of compelling migrants to leave is justified. 

Research questions: 
In light of the need to understand proportionality in immigration, we intend to address four primary questions, the first philosophical and the other three empirical:

1.	What mechanisms for immigration control are morally proportionate?
2.	Is there a relationship between citizens’ support for immigration control and the mechanisms used for this control?
3.	Is there a relationship between certain characteristics held by citizens (their education level, gender, etc.), or characteristics held by immigrants (education level, gender, etc.) and citizens’ tendency to support certain mechanisms for immigration control?
4.	Are there interaction effects between characteristics of citizens, characteristics of immigrants, and the mechanisms of immigration control that citizens support?

We have already begun philosophical work on the first question, and have considered the plausibility of the following two principles:

1.	With some exceptions, the more force used in mechanisms for immigration control, the less justified the immigration control is, all else being equal.  
2.	The use of direct force is either never justified, or only justified when the immigrant in question will directly or indirectly pose a threat to the life or basic necessities of innocent individuals.  

While more philosophical analysis will be pursued regarding the plausibility of the above two principles, the goal of the three empirical questions is partly to observe the extent that citizens’ opinions are consistent with these tentative philosophical principles.  Our first hypothesis is that they are to an extent. More specifically, we hypothesize the following:

1.	There is at least a weak inverse relationship between citizens’ support for exclusion and the extent that force used to bring about this exclusion causes likely harm. 
2.	There is at least a weak inverse relationship between citizens’ support for exclusion and the severity of the harm caused from force used to bring about this exclusion. 
3.	The more subjects are pro-humanitarian, the less they will support violent means of immigration control.
4.	The more educated subjects are, the less they will support violent means of immigration control.
5.	The subjects that are higher in trait empathy will support violent means of immigration control less. 
6.	Citizens will be more supportive of lethal force the more an immigrant is perceived as a threat to security.

2.	There is at least a weak inverse relationship between citizens’ support for exclusion and the severity of the harm caused from force used to bring about this exclusion. 
3.	The more subjects are pro-humanitarian, the less they will support violent means of immigration control.
4.	The more educated subjects are, the less they will support violent means of immigration control.
5.	The subjects that are higher in trait empathy will support violent means of immigration control less. 
6.	Citizens will be more supportive of lethal force the more an immigrant is perceived as a threat to security.

registration_responses.q6.question:
To test these hypotheses, we will conduct an online survey of using experimental vignettes (Atzmuller and Steiner 2010; Hainmueller et al 2015; Turper 2017) to evaluate the extent that subjects support or oppose the use of violence in immigration control. Subjects will be presented with eight vignettes involving a fictional migrant who seeks to enter or remain in the United Kingdom. They will be asked to decide the extent that denying this migrant the right to live in the UK is reasonable on a scale of 1 to 7. 

In addition to the above online survey, we will conduct in-person in-depth qualitative interviews to better understand why individuals support or object to a given means of immigration control and to understand individuals’ potential rationales behind views concerning immigration enforcement.
registration_responses.q10.question:
Payment and experiment completion time (finalized following pilot testing): 
£3.20 for a 25-minute experiment completed online.

Subject selection method: 
The sample of subjects for the online experiment will be collected from Prolific Academic and will be composed solely of individuals classified as British nationals.
registration_responses.q14.question:
Manipulated variables:
Each vignette will randomly vary along the following attributes:

Manipulated outside of the conjoint framework:
We have three experimental conditions based on the perceived likelihood of consequences of migration restrictions for migrants (though all tasks still remain hypothetical).  In Condition 1, participants are provided with certain information.   In Condition 2, participants are provided with information that is probabilistic (low, high, or near certain chances of consequences.  Finally, in Condition 3, participants are provided with no information about what happens to the migrant in the vignette.

Manipulated within the conjoint framework:
a.	Prospective (seeking to enter the UK) vs. retrospective (seeking to remain in the UK).
b.	Country of origin of migrant, collapsed by region (4 levels; Africa, Eastern Europe, Middle East, Asia)
a.	Africa:  Nigeria, Ethiopia, South Africa, Kenya
b.	Eastern Europe: Poland, Romania, Russia, Ukraine
c.	Middle East:  Iran, Syria, UAE, Israel
d.	Southeast Asia:  India, Bangladesh, Pakistan, Myanmar
c.	Migrants’ reasons for attempting to enter the UK.  More specifically, subjects will be randomly assigned vignettes with one of the following three variables: 
1)	Entering/wishing to remain in the UK to seek economic opportunity,
2)	Entering/wishing to remain in the UK to flee life-threatening poverty
3)	Entering/wishing to remain in the UK to flee persecution
4)	Entering/wishing to remain in the UK for medical treatment
d.	Their reasons for being denied a visa to live in the UK.
1)	They have a criminal record
2)	They lack employment in the UK 
3)	Their name is on a terrorism watch-list
4)	Immigration quotas do not permit it
5)	They are tested positive for COVID-19
e.	The means of removal of the migrant
1)	The method: detaining or deporting 
2)	The potential consequences:  
a.	bodily injury due to detention/deportation
b.	death due to detention/deportation
c.	bodily injury due to reason for immigration (e.g. illness) 
d.	death due to reason for immigration (e.g. illness)
e.	safe return to country of origin
f.	unknown
registration_responses.q15.question:
Measured variables:  (note:  full inclusion subject to duration of pre-tested survey)
1.	Key dependent variable:  Subjects will be asked how reasonable it is to support the exclusion/removal of a given immigrant in the vignettes described above. 
We will also measure the subject’s: 
2.	Gender 
3.	Education 
4.	Income
5.	Humanitarian orientation (Feldman and Steenbergen 2001)
6.	Reading the Mind in the Eyes task (Baron Cohen et al)
7.	Ideology
8.	Votes in previous elections
9.	Attitudes towards immigration restrictions in general, 
10.	Preferred methods of immigration control (deportation, detaining, denial access of healthcare, blanket amnesty, limited amnesty, no immigration control). 

The above measurements will be collected using a questionnaire found in the attached supplemental document, labeled, "Border_Control_Prolific_Study_March_2020."
registration_responses.q17.question:
We plan to analyse the results of the conjoint using OLS regression to model the impact of the experimental treatments and the conjoint attributes on the 7pt rating of how acceptable participants found the circumstances.  
We will also examine results for subgroup effects, in-line with our hypotheses, over the following characteristics:
1.	Humanitarianism 
2.	Empathy (Mind in the Eyes Task)
3.	Ideology
4.	Education
5.	Harshness of general immigration stance

All comparisons will be done by running separate models using the bottom and top quartiles on these scales/items.

attributes.title: Parenthood Identities Predict Impression Management
attributes.description: This project examines if parenting motivations increase impression management.

q2.value:
H1) Parenting motivations increase the desire for aesthetic products (vs. functional products).  
H2) H1 will be mediated by the perception that one's own social image impacts the social image of a child (proximal mediator) and increased impression management concerns (distal mediator).

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Participants will first view a slideshow priming parenting motivations or a control slideshow where they think about their everyday life. Afterwards, participants will make a selection between a functional sweater and an aesthetically pleasing, less functional sweater. Then, participants will answer questions regarding the mediators and answer questions checking the manipulation of the slideshow. Finally, they will answer demographic questions.

q7.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to the two slideshows - the parenting motivation prime vs. the control.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will collect participants from a student sample through a university's research portal.

q11.value: We will recruit 200 participants through from a behavioral laboratory.

q12.value: This sample is being used due to personnel constraints of participants in the laboratory.

q13.value: We will stop collecting data when we reach 200 participants.

question.value: We will manipulate parenting motivation through a slideshow. Half the participants will receive this slideshow, while the other half will receive a control slideshow where they think about their everyday life.

We will measure the following: 
1) Desire for the dependent variable product - preference between a functional sweater and an aesthetic (less functional) sweater
2) Feelings that their own social image impacts the social image of a child
3) Concern for impression management
4) Manipulation check of slideshow (i.e., feelings of being a parent).
5) Demographic variables (gender, age, income, parenthood status).

Feelings of being a parent (4 items; manipulation check) will be averaged into one variable. Additionally, the measures for the impression management concerns (3 items; distal mediator) will be combined into one item via creating a mean.
We will use an ANOVA to test the main effect. We will also use Hayes Process Macro to test the mediation model and the direct effect. 5000 bootstraps will be used.

q19.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct. The Hayes Process Analysis will use confidence intervals to test the efficacy of the mediation.

q20.value: No participants will be excluded unless they skip the dependent variable. Outliers will be left in the analyses. We will not include any awareness checks.

q21.value: We will use participants' data except for the missing items, which will be left missing. The only exception will be if they skip the dependent variable, in which case they will be excluded from all analyses.

attributes.title: Purpose in life, health messages receptivity, and loneliness among older adults during COVID-19 pandemic
attributes.description:
***** See https://osf.io/39vfg for an updated version ***** 
The COVID-19 pandemic is posing a direct threat to the health of millions across the globe. In particular, elderly population faces the highest risk of severe illness and mortality from COVID-19, such that 8 out of 10 deaths caused by COVID-19 in the U.S. have been in adults 65 years old and older (CDC.gov). Avoiding close contact with others by putting physical distance between people, or “social distancing,” has been considered one of the most effective strategies to slow the spread of coronavirus and is strongly recommended and/or enforced by many nations across the world. While social distancing is critical to stay safe during pandemic, it can also increase risks associated with social isolation and loneliness, especially for older adults who are already vulnerable due to various conditions that prevent them from maintaining close social contacts. In the U.S., for example, older compared to younger adults are more likely to live alone (1) with reduced mobility, and their social circles tend to be smaller due to loss of friends and family (2). Further, they tend to suffer more from social isolation (3) compared to younger counterparts, with often fewer resources to carry out daily activities independently and cope with feelings of loneliness. Feelings of loneliness might also motivate older adults to downplay the importance of social distancing and venture out of their homes to social gatherings, which may expose them to greater dangers of infection during pandemic. Therefore, testing effective psychological interventions that may increase the likelihood for older adults of maintaining social distance while not increasing loneliness is critical. This way, vulnerable older populations are protected from direct threats of infectious disease as well as indirect threats of loneliness and social isolation that may result from measures taken to prevent the spread of virus.

Having a strong sense of purpose in life, or a set of goals derived from an individual’s core values, has been consistently associated with a wide range of positive health outcomes. Having a higher sense of purpose in life is uniquely associated with increased longevity (4), reduced risk of age-related conditions such as heart diseases (5) and cognitive impairment (6), and healthier lifestyles that are key to wellbeing in old age, including physical activity (7) and the use of preventative health services (8). Importantly, purpose may decrease loneliness and promote receptivity to health messaging. Higher purpose has been associated with less perceived loneliness among older adults (9), though less is known about the causal link. Further, our previous work suggests that purpose in life may increase receptivity to health messages, such that individuals with greater sense of purpose in life showed lower conflict-related neural responses while exposed to health messages, which then predicted the likelihood of them agreeing with the self-relevant health messages (10). Together, evidence suggests that increasing purpose might be an effective strategy to shield older adults from the virus as well as loneliness during times of global pandemic.

The proposed study will test the effects of purpose in life on loneliness and receptivity to COVID-19 messages in older adults. Study 1 will test the links among individual differences in purpose in life, perceived loneliness, and COVID-19 related responses (i.e., intentions, norms, and beliefs). Study 2, which will be amended to this preregistration after initial rounds of pilot will causally manipulate purpose in life by reminding people of values shared across their social group and test its effects on perceived loneliness and responses to COVID-19 related measures. Age will be tested as a moderator in both studies.
attributes.withdrawal_justification: The larger study this preregistration is part of decided to have the same exclusion criteria for all studies that share its dataset. We withdrew the current preregistration and created a new one that has updated criteria based on this decision.

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

other.value: The data collection has started on 4/6/2020 but is not complete. No data have been downloaded or analyzed. Please see “exploratory” items under hypotheses and analyses.

sample.value: The current study will use a subset of a larger preregistered study (https://osf.io/cmr25/). As part of this larger study, we conducted a small pilot study to assess potential effect sizes and variance parameters. Based on these results, we conducted a power analysis using the PANGEA power calculator and determined we would have >80% power to detect an effect size of d = .2 for within- and between-subject effects with N = 200 per each of the 5 experimental conditions plus an additional 100 people expecting 10% data loss (N = 1100). The variables in the proposed study will be collected from 660 participants of this sample. Based on results from a smaller pilot described above, we will need at least 112 participants to have 80% power to detect the effects proposed in the current preregistration, so the current sample will give us strong power to detect these effects.

analyses.value:
H1a. Higher self-reported purpose in life will be associated with less perceived loneliness.
lm(loneliness ~ purpose, data=df)

H1b. Age will be tested as a potential moderator for H1a, such that higher purpose is more strongly associated with less loneliness for older adults compared to younger adults
lm(loneliness ~ purpose*age, data=df)

H2. Higher self-reported purpose in life will be associated with more positive responses to COVID-19 related measures, including intentions, norms, and beliefs.
lm(intentions ~ purpose, data=df)
lm(norms ~ purpose, data=df)
lm(beliefs_norms ~ purpose, data=df)
lm(beliefs_protect_others ~ purpose, data=df)
lm(beliefs_protect_self ~ purpose, data=df)
 
Exploratory1. We will test whether higher perceived loneliness will be associated with more negative responses to COVID-19 related measures, including intentions, norms, and beliefs
lm(intentions ~ loneliness, data=df)
lm(norms ~ loneliness, data=df)
lm(beliefs_norms ~ loneliness, data=df)
lm(beliefs_protect_others ~ loneliness, data=df)
lm(beliefs_protect_self ~ loneliness, data=df)
 
 
Exploratory2. Analyses including loneliness will be repeated with potential covariates, including number of household members, SES, and gender.
lm(loneliness ~ purpose + household_members + SES + gender, data=df)
lm(intentions ~ loneliness + household_members + SES + gender, data=df)
lm(norms ~ loneliness + household_members + SES + gender, data=df)
lm(beliefs_norms ~ loneliness + household_members + SES + gender, data=df)
lm(beliefs_protect_others ~ loneliness + household_members + SES + gender, data=df)
lm(beliefs_protect_self ~ loneliness + household_members + SES + gender, data=df)
 
Exploratory3. We will repeat the analyses that include COVID-19 related measures (intentions, beliefs, and norms) by focusing on only the items explicitly related to social distancing (see “Dependent variables”)
df$intentions_sd <- (df$intentions2 + df$intentions4 + df$intentions6 + df$intentions10)/4
df$norms_sd <- (df$norms2 + df$norms4 + df$norms6 + df$norms10)/4

Exploratory4. We will repeat the analyses described above using a subset of the sample with participants who were randomly assigned to a condition where they did not receive any COVID-19 messages.
df2 =subset (df,condition=='no message control')

outliers.value: We will exclude individual responses that are missing from analyses. Outliers that are more than 3 SDs from the mean will be winsorized to +/- 3 SD.

dependent.value:
1. Intentions to engage in behaviors to slow the spread of COVID-19
Please rate how much you intend to do the following things over the next two weeks (1 = definitely won’t, 7 = definitely will) (we will average the responses to the following items)
1) Wash my hands for at least 20 seconds with soap and warm water each time I wash them
2) Stay home and avoid all social contact, even if I’m not sick (social distancing)
3) Stay home if I’m sick
4) Limit my grocery shopping to once a week or less (social distancing)
5) Work from home every day I need to work
6) Stay at least 6 feet apart from others when I’m in public (social distancing)
7) Touch commonly used surfaces (e.g. doorknobs) with my hands when I’m in public
8) Touch my face when I’m in public
9) Shake hands when I meet others
10) Avoid all public gatherings, even if I’m not sick (social distancing)

2. Perceived social norms (0-100%). For these questions, think about your closest friends and family. What proportion of them will do the following things in the next two weeks? (0%-100%) (we will average the responses to the following items)
Same ten items as in “1. Intentions”, above.

3.    	Beliefs regarding COVID-19 (we will average the responses to the following items within each category) (1 = strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree)

Norms
1) It will be awkward to avoid my friends.
2) My family will approve of my decision.
3) My friends will approve of my decision.

Protect others
1) I will keep my family safe.
2) I will keep people in my community safe.
3) I will prevent others from getting COVID-19.
4) I will protect more vulnerable people in our society.
5) I will slow the spread of COVID-19.
6) It will be good for society.
7) It will help stop the spread of COVID-19.
8) It will help the healthcare system from being over flooded and enable people who need urgent medical care to receive it.

Protecting the self
1) I will avoid coming in contact with coronavirus.
2) I will be less likely to get COVID-19.
3) I will be less likely to get sick.
4) I will keep myself safe.
5) I will be able to take care of myself.

hypothesis.value:
This study will use a subset of a larger study examining message framing effects and includes five different message framing conditions. The study variables relevant to the proposed questions will be collected from a subset of the entire sample (see “sample size”), where some will be randomly assigned to view differently framed messages while others see no messages. Therefore, the condition assignment will be entered as a covariate in all analyses described below.

H1a. Higher self-reported purpose in life will be associated with less perceived loneliness.

Exploratory4. We will repeat the analyses described above using a subset of the sample with participants who were randomly assigned to a condition where they did not receive any COVID-19 messages.

attributes.title: Purpose in life, health messages receptivity, and loneliness among older adults during COVID-19 pandemic
attributes.description:
***** This is an updated preregistration from https://osf.io/yacjz. The updates include: 1) that the team agreed on SOP for exclusions before looking at any data, 2) description of one of the dependent measure that was previously missing is added (loneliness), and 3) license information *****

The COVID-19 pandemic is posing a direct threat to the health of millions across the globe. In particular, elderly population faces the highest risk of severe illness and mortality from COVID-19, such that 8 out of 10 deaths caused by COVID-19 in the U.S. have been in adults 65 years old and older (CDC.gov). Avoiding close contact with others by putting physical distance between people, or “social distancing,” has been considered one of the most effective strategies to slow the spread of coronavirus and is strongly recommended and/or enforced by many nations across the world. While social distancing is critical to stay safe during pandemic, it can also increase risks associated with social isolation and loneliness, especially for older adults who are already vulnerable due to various conditions that prevent them from maintaining close social contacts. In the U.S., for example, older compared to younger adults are more likely to live alone (1) with reduced mobility, and their social circles tend to be smaller due to loss of friends and family (2). Further, they tend to suffer more from social isolation (3) compared to younger counterparts, with often fewer resources to carry out daily activities independently and cope with feelings of loneliness. Feelings of loneliness might also motivate older adults to downplay the importance of social distancing and venture out of their homes to social gatherings, which may expose them to greater dangers of infection during pandemic. Therefore, testing effective psychological interventions that may increase the likelihood for older adults of maintaining social distance while not increasing loneliness is critical. This way, vulnerable older populations are protected from direct threats of infectious disease as well as indirect threats of loneliness and social isolation that may result from measures taken to prevent the spread of virus.

Having a strong sense of purpose in life, or a set of goals derived from an individual’s core values, has been consistently associated with a wide range of positive health outcomes. Having a higher sense of purpose in life is uniquely associated with increased longevity (4), reduced risk of age-related conditions such as heart diseases (5) and cognitive impairment (6), and healthier lifestyles that are key to wellbeing in old age, including physical activity (7) and the use of preventative health services (8). Importantly, purpose may decrease loneliness and promote receptivity to health messaging. Higher purpose has been associated with less perceived loneliness among older adults (9), though less is known about the causal link. Further, our previous work suggests that purpose in life may increase receptivity to health messages, such that individuals with greater sense of purpose in life showed lower conflict-related neural responses while exposed to health messages, which then predicted the likelihood of them agreeing with the self-relevant health messages (10). Together, evidence suggests that increasing purpose might be an effective strategy to shield older adults from the virus as well as loneliness during times of global pandemic.

The proposed study will test the effects of purpose in life on loneliness and receptivity to COVID-19 messages in older adults. Study 1 will test the links among individual differences in purpose in life, perceived loneliness, and COVID-19 related responses (i.e., intentions, norms, and beliefs). Study 2, which will be amended to this preregistration after initial rounds of pilot will causally manipulate purpose in life by reminding people of values shared across their social group and test its effects on perceived loneliness and responses to COVID-19 related measures. Age will be tested as a moderator in both studies.

attributes.title: Efficacy and safety of oral traditional Chinese medicine for allergic rhinitis: protocol for a systematic review and meta analysis
attributes.description: Allergic rhinitis (AR) is a common symptomatic, inflammatory and immunological disorder of nasal mucosa results from allergen exposure triggered IgE response. Epidemiology of allergic rhinitis varies according to different factors like genetic constitution, racial differences, socio-economic conditions, chances of exposure to different allergens, sex, growth stages. AR shows high prevalence among developed countries. AR is managed with first and second anti histamines (56%), intra nasal corticosteroids (25%) and mast cell stabilizers (19%). Prolonged usage of these medications is necessary in beating the disease as far as the recurrence is concerned. This may lead to numerous serious health hazards. Studies have shown that negative effects of sedative anti-histamines last to the succeeding day disturbing the day time performance. Traditional Chinese medicine in the treatment of allergic rhinitis has done a lot of research, the effect is significant. Therefore, research on it is needed.

q1.value: Qinxiu Zhang, Deyun Wang, Lei Cheng, Yan Ruan, Peng Liu, Kexin Hu, Xuanpu Gong, Jinhui Liu, Rongchang Feng, Jianying Gao, Hui Xie, Xinrong Li, Qinwei Fu

q2.value:
1. Oral traditional Chinese medicine is effective for treatment of patients with allergic rhinitis.
2. How does the efficacy of oral traditional Chinese medicine compare to that with Western medicine therapies alone, other TCM therapies alone, blank control, placebo control and other interventions? 
3. There are some moderating variables associated with treatment efficacy in studies of oral traditional Chinese medicine for patients with the allergic rhinitis.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

q5.value:
Three reviewers searched the online databases listed above and recorded the titles and abstracts of all the articles.
Three evaluators assessed the eligibility of these articles and made decisions on every research (inclusion or exclusion) independently. If they did not reach the same decision, the concerned articles were discussed with a fourth reviewer.
Three reviewers extracted data independently from each study.
Differences regarding the extracted data were resolved after discussion with a fourth reviewer.
Three authors of our review team will independently assess the methodological quality of included trials, and consensus will be reached by discussion with a third party in case of discrepancy.

The methodological quality of RCTs will be assessed according to the risk of bias tool described in the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions [Higgins JPT 2009]. Six elements will be assessed: random sequence generation, allocation concealment, blinding of outcome assessors, incomplete outcome data, free of selective reporting, and other bias. Disagreements will be resolved by discussion with a third party.

question.value:
1. Anticipated start date: 07/04/2020;

2. Anticipated completion date: 28/05/2020;

3.Review question: ①. 1. Is oral traditional Chinese medicine an effective treatment for patiens with allergic rhinitis?
                                  ②. How does the efficacy of oral traditional Chinese medicine compare to that with having western medicines, blank control, placebo control and other interventions?
                                  ③. What moderating variables are associated with treatment effectiveness in studies of oral traditional Chinese medicine for patients with allergic rhinitis? 

4. Searches: English databases including PubMed, Embase, Cochrane Library and Chinese databases including CNKI, Wanfang, VIP databases will be searched. The research will start following the PRISMA protocol.
The terms used in the search will follow the rules of the Medical Subject Headings (MeSH) and the question that guided the search was based on the PICOS strategy (participants, interventions, comparison, results and studies). search strategy information can be found in the attached PDF document (link provided below).
One week will be allocated for data collection and one week for article analysis.
Retrieval time is from the inception dates of the databases to 19 Apri, 2020.
We also considered the alternative terms and spellings for keywords.
In addition, the references of initially included literature were traced back to achieve a comprehensive search. English and Chinese language were included.

5. Condition or domain being studied: Allergic rhinitis (AR) is a common symptomatic, inflammatory and immunological disorder of nasal mucosa results from allergen exposure triggered IgE response. Epidemiology of allergic rhinitis varies according to different factors like genetic constitution, racial differences, socio-economic conditions, chances of exposure to different allergens, sex, growth stages. AR shows high prevalence among developed countries. AR is managed with first and second anti histamines (56%), intra nasal corticosteroids (25%) and mast cell stabilizers (19%). Prolonged usage of these medications is necessary in beating the disease as far as the recurrence is concerned. This may lead to numerous serious health hazards. Studies have shown that negative effects of sedative anti-histamines last to the succeeding day disturbing the day time performance. Therefore, research on it is needed.

6.Participants/population: Participants with all types of allergic rhinitis (including intermittent allergic rhinitis and persistent allergic rhinitis) regardless of gender, age, etiology, ethnic group, severity, diagnosed with specific criteria (i.e. mention any one of criteria for diagnosis of allergic rhinitis) are eligible for inclusion. Complicated with asthma, nasosinusitis are excluded.

7. Intervention(s), exposure(s): Treatment of oral traditional Chinese medicine, including pill, powder, paste, ingot and other dosage forms.

8. Comparator(s)/control: Including having western medicines, blank control, placebo control and other interventions. Interventions in the experimental group were not included.

9. Types of study to be included: We will include randomised controlled trials (RCTs), published and unpublished, in English and Chinese.

10. Main outcome(s): ①Total Nasal Symptom Score (TNSS) and four key symptoms' scores;
                                      ②Rhinitis Quality of Life Questionnaire (RQLQ); 
                                      ③VAS score;
                                      ④Total effective rate;
                                      ⑤Score for signs and symptoms;
                                      ⑥The improvement of disease classification.

11. Additional outcome(s): ① TNNSS;
                                                ②Laboratory index, eg. IgE, IL;
                                                ③Recurrence rate;
                                                ④Time when the symptoms disappear;
                                                ⑤Frequency of seizure;
                                                ⑥The case of drug reduction.

12. Data extraction (selection and coding): Three reviewers searched the online databases listed above and recorded the titles and abstracts of all the articles.
Three evaluators assessed the eligibility of these articles and made decisions on every research (inclusion or exclusion) independently. If they did not reach the same decision, the concerned articles were discussed with a fourth reviewer.
Three reviewers extracted data independently from each study.
Differences regarding the extracted data were resolved after discussion with a fourth reviewer.

13.Risk of bias (quality) assessment: Three authors of our review team will independently assess the methodological quality of included trials, and consensus will be reached by discussion with a third party in case of discrepancy.
The methodological quality of RCTs will be assessed according to the risk of bias tool described in the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions [Higgins JPT 2009]. Six elements will be assessed: random sequence generation, allocation concealment, blinding of outcome assessors, incomplete outcome data, free of selective reporting, and other bias. Disagreements will be resolved by discussion with a third party.

14. Strategy for data synthesis: Statistical analyses will be performed using RevMan 5.3 software (The Cochrane Collaboration).
- Pooled risk ratio (RR) with 95% confidence interval (CI) of dichotomous outcomes will be used to report effect estimate.
- Continuous data will be presented as mean difference (MD) with 95% CI. If different measurement scales are used, standardized mean difference (SMD) will be performed to analyze continuous data.
If required data are not reported, we will try to obtain data from corresponding author.
Heterogeneity will be assessed using both the χ² test and the I² statistic, and we will consider an I² value greater than 50% indicative of substantial heterogeneity.
- For I²<50%, a fixed-effect model is used.
- For I² >=50%, a random-effect model is applied.
If data permit, we plan to exclude some trials that contribuite most to the heterogeneity to see whether the result change or not.
We will also use a summary of findings table to present the main findings using GRADEpro software (The Cochrane Collaboration). Funnel plots will be generated to detect publication bias if more than 10 trials are identified to report the same outcomes. If appropriate, we will use cumulative meta-analyses. Results of meta-analyses will be visualized by forest plots. In addition, we will conduct trial sequential analysis to evaluate the meta-analyses for primary outcomes, which can reveal the required information size and potentially false results in a meta-analysis. Intention-to-treat analysis will be applied for primary outcome, if missing data from the original trials are available.

15. Analysis of subgroups or subsets: If data permitted, we plan to conduct subgroup analyses for different groups, including:
Different age of patients
Different severity of disease
Different regimen applied
Different treat time
Different acupoints selected
Combined with other interventions or not.

17. Health area of the review: Complementary therapies; Allergy; Public health; ENT; 

18. Languages of the review: English and Chinese;

19. Dissemination plans: In addition to producing a report, a paper will be submitted to a journal in this field.

attributes.description: This project is examining the effect of parenting motivations on products that enhance social image.

q2.value:
H1) Parenting motivations increase the desire for aesthetic products (vs. functional products).  
H2) H1 will be mediated by the perception that one's own social image impacts the social image of a child (proximal mediator) and increased impression management concerns (distal mediator).

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: Participants will first view a slideshow priming parenting motivations or a control slideshow where they think about their everyday life. Afterwards, they will answer a set of mediation questions testing if 1) parenting primes increase perceptions that one's social image impacts the social image of a child, and 2) concern for impression management. Then, participants will make a selection between a functional phone and an aesthetically pleasing, less functional phone. Then, participants will answer questions checking that the manipulation of the slideshows worked as intended. Finally, they will answer demographic questions.

q7.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to the two slideshows - the parenting motivation prime vs. the control.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will collect data using TurkPrime. Participants will be told that they are completing a study on perception. They will be paid $.35. Participants will be allowed to complete this study as long as they have not completed other studies that have been apart of the same project.

q11.value: We will recruit 240 participants through TurkPrime.

q12.value: A power analysis based on earlier data suggested that we needed at least 240 participants.

q13.value: TurkPrime occasionally includes a few extra participants. Therefore, our stopping rule will be to stop when TurkPrime states that the study has been completed.

question.value: We will manipulate parenting motivation through a slideshow. Half the participants will receive this slideshow, while the other half will receive a control slideshow where they think about their everyday life.

We will measure the following: 
1) Desire for the dependent variable product - preference between a functional phone and an aesthetic (less functional) phone
2) Feelings that their own social image impacts the social image of a child
3) Concern for impression management
4) Manipulation check of slideshow (i.e., feelings of being a parent).
5) Demographic variables (gender, age, income, parenthood status).

Feelings of being a parent (4 items; manipulation check) will be averaged into one variable. Additionally, the measures for the impression management concerns (3 items; distal mediator) will be combined into one item via creating a mean.
We will use an ANOVA to test the main effect. We will also use Hayes Process Macro to test the mediation model and the direct effect. 5000 bootstraps will be used.

q19.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct. The Hayes Process Analysis will use confidence intervals to test the efficacy of the mediation.

q20.value: No participants will be excluded unless they skip the dependent variable. Outliers will be left in the analyses. We will not include any awareness checks.

q21.value: We will use participants' data except for the missing items, which will be left missing. The only exception will be if they skip the dependent variable, in which case they will be excluded from all analyses.

attributes.title: Reward processing
attributes.description: The current study is part of a larger project with the aim to investigate reward processing and pupillary responses in MDD. The current sample is a control group, where participants have no current MDD symptoms, but approximately one third has an history of MDD-episodes. We aim to investigate if there are any differences in reward learning and pupillary responses in a shifting reward learning task with two contingencies, one showing at face (happy/sad) as feedback and one showing a thumb (up/down) as feedback.
